source.ce1c76f5:
parlimen = pd.read_csv("../input/malaysia-ge14-election-results-parliament/Election-Results-2018 - Parlimen_Results_By_Candidate.csv")

#Cleaning the data 
parlimen['Votes for Candidate']= parlimen['Votes for Candidate'].str.replace(",","").astype(int) #Getting rid of the ',' and changing into int 
parlimen['% of total Votes'] = parlimen['% of total Votes'].str.strip('%.').astype(float)
parlimen['Total Votes Cast']= parlimen['Total Votes Cast'].str.replace(",","").astype(int)
parlimen
source.732a638e:
parlimen_mng= parlimen[(parlimen['Status'] == "MNG")]
parlimen_mng= parlimen_mng.drop(columns =["Status",'Candidate Win'])
parlimen_mng
source.6a60790d:
fig = px.pie(parlimen_mng, values='Votes for Candidate',names='Coalition',title='Party Percentage that makes up State Results by Candidate under GE14 ')
fig.show()
source.c655ceeb:
kerja = pd.DataFrame(parlimen["Pekerjaan"].value_counts())
kerja.reset_index(inplace=True)
kerja["index"].replace({'TIADA': 'NaN',"0":'NaN',"-":"NaN"},inplace=True)
kerja_bs = kerja[(kerja["Pekerjaan"]>5)]
kerja_bs
source.819638b8:
fig = px.pie(kerja_bs, values='Pekerjaan',names='index',title='Pekerjaan for each winning candidates under GE14 ')
fig.show()

population = pd.DataFrame({'State':['Sabah', 'Perak', 'Johor', 'Selangor', 'Kelantan', 'Pahang', 'Pulau Pinang', 'Kedah', 'Negeri Sembilan', 'Terengganu', 'Melaka', 'Sarawak', 'Perlis', 'Wilayah Persekutuan (KL)', 
                                    'Wilayah Persekutuan (Putrajaya)', 'Wilayah Persekutuan (Labuan)'], 'Seat':[85, 83, 82, 78, 59, 56, 53, 51, 44, 40, 34, 31, 18, 11, 1, 1], 
                           'Population':[3903400, 2512100, 3764300, 6528400, 1885700, 1674600, 1774600, 2180600, 1130300, 1245700, 930700, 2812800, 254400, 1780700, 103800, 99300]})
population
source.b214a76f:
seats = pd.read_csv("../input/malaysia-ge14-election-results-parliament/Election-Results-2018 - Total_Votes_by_Seat.csv")
seats['Total Registered Votes']= seats['Total Registered Votes'].str.replace(",","").astype(int)
seats['Votes for ALL Candidate']= seats['Votes for ALL Candidate'].str.replace(",","").astype(int)
seats['Spoilt Votes']= seats['Spoilt Votes'].str.replace(",","").astype(int)
seats
source.6f012415:
# Combining the two datasets into one table for better observation 
votes = seats.groupby("State")["Votes for ALL Candidate",'Spoilt Votes',"Total Registered Votes"].sum().reset_index()
result = pd.merge(votes, population, how="inner", on=["State", "State"])
result
source.0b45983c:
result['Number of votes needed to win'] = (result['Total Registered Votes'] - result['Spoilt Votes']) / result['Seat']

Average = result['Number of votes needed to win'].mean()
print(f'Average number of votes required for one seat :{Average:.0f}')
source.04876dc5:
print('Number of Parliament Seat :',seats[(seats.Type == 'PARLIMEN')].count()['Seat'])
print('Number of DUN Seat :',seats[(seats.Type == 'DUN')].count()['Seat'])
source.a241e59f:
Total = Average*112
f"Number of Votes needed to form a Federal Government:  {Total:.0f}"
source.3f33f124:
from pywaffle import Waffle
Gender = dict(parlimen_mng.Gender.value_counts())
fig = plt.figure(
    FigureClass=Waffle,
    values=Gender,
    rows=4,
    columns = 8,
    colors=["#232066", "#983D3D"],
    icons=['male','female'],
    font_size=60,
    icon_style='solid',
    icon_legend=True,
    interval_ratio_x=3,
    interval_ratio_y=4,
    legend={
        'labels': ['male', 'female'], 
        'loc': 'upper left',
    'bbox_to_anchor': (0, -0.1)})
fig.show()

source.ed9e74bf:
data = youth.dropna()
speak = data.loc[:,['Assertiveness',"Number of friends","Public speaking","Fear of public speaking","Finances","Spending on looks","Branded clothing","Empathy","Elections","Decision making","Gender","all"]]
speak
source.0a7221ae:
speak2 = speak.iloc[:,:9]
corr = speak.corr()

# Generate a mask for the upper triangle
mask = np.triu(np.ones_like(corr, dtype=bool))

# Set up the matplotlib figure
f, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(11, 9))

# Generate a custom diverging colormap
cmap = sns.diverging_palette(230, 20, as_cmap=True)

# Draw the heatmap with the mask and correct aspect ratio
sns.heatmap(corr, mask=mask, cmap=cmap, vmax=.3, center=0,
            square=True, linewidths=.5, cbar_kws={"shrink": .5},annot=True)

## <u>Outliers</u> 
>### As you can see theres a huge outlier where we are counting all the values of various heights but sadly its very skewed since were taking into account of extreme values . These are called outliers and as much as we want to make sure everyone is inclusive , we also want to make a good observation on what the majority of data hence its often a good idea to get rid of extreme values such as outliers.

source.f7fb0f7d: ## Observation >### **Correlation coefficients** are indicators of the strength of the linear relationship between two different variables, x and y. A linear correlation coefficient that is greater than zero indicates a positive relationship. A value that is less than zero signifies a negative relationship. >### So by logic , Its correlation fo youths who spend on looks vs youth who spend on branded clothing has a very high positive realtionship .As well as people who are well prepared before a public speaking has a definite relationship with peeople who have a fear of public speaking.

source.f79144e5:
## This Table Contains:- ### PERSONALITY TRAITS, VIEWS ON LIFE & OPINIONS ##### **[Assertiveness]** *I am not afraid to give my opinion if I feel strongly about something.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer) ##### **[Public speaking]** *I have to be well prepared before public speaking.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer)
##### **[Elections]** *I always try to vote in elections.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer)
##### **[Empathy]***I am emphatetic person.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer)
##### **[Decision making]** *I take my time to make decisions.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer)
##### **[Number of friends]** *I have lots of friends.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer)
### SPENDING HABITS ##### **[Finances]** *I save all the money I can.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer) ##### **[Branded clothing]** *I prefer branded clothing to non branded.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer) ##### **[Spending on looks]** *I spend a lot of money on my appearance.*: Strongly disagree 1-2-3-4-5 Strongly agree (integer) ### PHOBIAS ##### **[Fear of public speaking]** *Public speaking*: Not afraid at all 1-2-3-4-5 Very afraid of (integer)

source.d1032348:
# 2) Can Youths Speak Up ?
>### Often times , most adults hope for youths to come with better solutions and ideass to change our society but whether our voices are heard or we were given the chance to make a change is still subject of descretion . Lets take a look on whether really do speak up over issues that matter the most. >### Unfortunately , theres no substantial data specifically on Malaysian youths that I can conduct a deep analysis for this study hence I'm using data from the **Young People Survey** made by Faculty of Social and Economic Sciences UK from 2017 to have in depth look of youths are thinking , to show an example of how we can conduct this study

source.2ea09031: ### This is a case study project that i'm making for my Undi18 Job Application in which I'm observing two types of datas which consists of ## 1. GE14 Exploratory Data Analysis > ### *GE15 is in the air for 2021 as it comes closer every day , I want to make an interesting observation on the impact of GE14 and share some interesting insight of what data such as the gender ratio of our ( then ) elected officials as well as how valuable our vote can be in directly influencing our government as well as the whole nation* ## 2. Can Youth's Speak Up ? > ### *This is an analysis on youths from the dataset made by Faculty of Social and Economic Sciences UK from various aspects such as taste of music to various phobias such as fear of heights . I choose this dataset as sadly theres no comparable public dataset featuring malaysian youths.* ### I'll be sharing some of my observations as as well showcasing some statistical analysis on each dataset .
source.87c380f2:
# <u>Observation</u> 
>### Based on observation alone , we can see the height difference between village and city have two varrying differences with a slight bump on between 180cm -190cm which shows that the youths within cities have a bigger variety of heights due to the fact that more youths live in cities . 

>### In conclusion its important to know the outliers in order to get a much better visualization of the data since we can view the chart  more clearly and create a more accurate observation
